Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Extreme Climate Events in the Holocene Controlled by El-Ni√±o-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Anomalies: Millennia-Long Stalagmite Records from the Southwest Pacific
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the utility of speleothems from the Island of Niue as archives of climate information from the Southwest Pacific (SWP) region.

The scientific objectives of the study are to: (i) acquire high resolution time-series of oxygen and carbon isotopes from speleothems spanning the Holocene; (ii) derive precise absolute chronology of the records based on a combined use of uranium/thorium dating method and floating-lamina counting chronology (iii) improve the understanding of carbon isotope variability in Niuean stalagmites; (iv) better understand rainfall variability in the SWP; and (vi) assess tropical and extra-tropical linkages by comparing contemporaneous proxy climate records

The primary broader impacts involve collecting data from a sparsely sampled region, creating a uniquely strong sampling strategy between modern precipitation and cave deposits, supporting undergraduate and graduate students, and building strong international collaboration with colleagues and students from Niue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The El-Niño Sothern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon is the strongest source of natural variability in the Earth's climate system at present and its impact is felt globally far beyond the source. An understanding of the past irregularity and strength beyond the instrumental records, available only for the past century, will give important clues to the climate future in a greenhouse world. Past records of ENSO variability in the Tropical Pacific are scarce and typically limitted to century-long archives from coral heads. Whereas speleothem studies are presently at the forefront of investigations into regional and global climate dynamics, such studies are non-existent in the vast ocean area between Australia and South America. This study offers proxy climate records from stalagmites in caves on Niue Island (19o 00'S; 169o 50'W) in the tropical Southwest Pacific that exhibit centennial to millennia long high resolution (subannual) ENSO variability under contrasting climate states. This study recognized two principal type of caves on Niue Island: (i) steeply inclined, terraced, caves that formed at the seaward edge of the groundwater lense and breach the vertical cliffs on the leeward side of the island (flank-margin caves), and (ii) flat-roofed, inland caves consisting of interconnected passages that developed at the paleo-water table and are presently uplifted above the water table. Observations, caves mapping, dripwaters and stalagmites sampling were carry out on two selected caves representing the two cave types above. Rainfall samples were collected at weekly intervals during a five years period (June 2011 to June 2015) from a rainfall gauge installed on the premises of the Niue Meteorological Office. Stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes were measured in the laboratory for the purpose of calibrating the isotope proxies against the rainfall amount. Additionally, dripwaters from two drip sites were collected monthly from the caves over the period July 2011 to May 2013  in order to link the rainfall isotopes with the drip isotopes. Power-Spectra Analysis (PSA) of Niue Monthly Rainfall Anomalies (NMRA), acquired over a period of 100 years (1906-2006), exhibit periodicities of 3-5 years, ~24 and ~40 years that match well with ENSO, the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) and the Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation (IPO) periodicities.

High resolution (sub-annual) records of δ18O and δ13C were acquired from
the stalagmites whose precise chronology was established by radiometric
methods. Century-long young stalagmites overlapping instrumental climate
records were used to test the fidelity of the proxy δ18O and δ13C records.
PSA application to the proxy rainfall data demonstrated that stalagmites from Niue Island located at the epicenter of ENSO can be successfully harnessed as paleorainfall archives.

A stalagmite dated by multiple-techniques (band-floating chronology; AMS radiocarbon and U/Th by MC-ICPMS ) was found to contain 500 years of record (AD 2000-1500) and a mean growth rate of 98 ±40 μm/yr. Identification of ENSO events in the stable isotope time-series acquired at 0.4 yr resolution offers valuable insights into the frequency changes of ENSO events in the past 500 years. The results indicate that El-Niños were weaker and more frequent 500 years ago with 24 events/century whereas in recent times their frequency dropped to 16 events/century with intensified strength.
